title: How to Install an Inwall Air Conditioner

steps.headline: Pick a location where the AC will be installed.
steps.description: Try not to locate above electrics and electronics because they may be damaged by condensation from the discharge air grates on very humid days. Plan to keep the bottom of the unit 1 to 5 feet (30 to 150 cm) from the floor to minimize dust from the floor clogging the filter, and condensation forming on the ceiling.

steps.headline: Locate the wall studs.
steps.description:
Use a stud finder, visually inspect baseboards for nail heads, or rap on the walls with your knuckles—you can hear the sound change from hollow to solid as you rap over a stud. (Commonly, studs are 16 inches apart in the U.S.) Lightly indicate with pencil on the wall where these studs lie. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Roughly indicate the layout of the AC unit on the wall, in such a way that the number of studs to be removed are minimized. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}

steps.headline: Clear the area.
Transfer the dimensions of the AC unit or sleeve to the inside of the outside wall.
steps.description: Set the placement of the exhaust opening so that the top will fall just under the edge of a full clapboard, shingle, or other siding section—wherever it will be most aesthetically pleasing (or rather, least aesthetically displeasing).

steps.headline: Create the hole for the outside of the unit.
steps.description: Mark the outside opening using a template if provided by the AC manufacturer, or draw one in. If you draw your own template, use a framing square and level to ensure that your opening is level and square. Add 1/4 inch to the height of the opening. This additional 1/4 inch will allow the unit to be angled slightly downward on the outside to prevent condensation and rainwater from collecting in the unit and leaking inside the house. If you have a specific point for the top of the opening, add this 1/4 inch to the bottom for the new line to cut. Carefully create the opening by cutting along the lines with a Sawzall.

steps.headline: Build supports.
steps.description: Cut a stud to fit against the two studs that make the sides of the opening created for the AC unit. Level and install at the bottom edge of the AC unit location. Cut a board to fit between the wall stud on the floor in the wall space and the bottom AC support installed in the previous step. Screw or nail these studs to the existing studs. There should be three (possibly four if the unit is very large) new vertical studs in the space below the unit; all of which run from the bottom to the underside of the horizontal support; one in the middle, one against the existing left stud and one against the existing right stud.

steps.headline: Fabricate a header.
Add studs.
steps.description: Cut a 2-by to fit between the header and the top plate (the 2-by that the left- and right-most studs are secured to at the top) plus 1/8 inch at the left-most stud and nail or screw into place. Hammer these studs into position. Repeat for the right-most stud and for at least as many vertical studs installed in previous steps below the unit, in the space above the new header. If one stud was cut and installed in the middle of the wall space for the bottom support of the unit, then at least one (but more would be better) will be required above the opening as well. These studs above the header should fit tightly. If not a tight fit, cracks may develop on the wall surface  as the weight settles on the new framework in the wall.

steps.headline: Finish the frame.
steps.description: Cut two 2-bys equal to the height of the opening. Making this cut a little long (1/16 inch or so) will help ensure settling will not reduce the opening and minimize any movement. Hammer these 2-bys along the left and right side of the opening. Nail or screw in place.

steps.headline: Install any electrical outlets required while the wall is open.
steps.description: If the unit is high on the wall, consider installing an appropriately rated switch at this time for the outlet, as this will make powering the unit on and off easier. It will also reduce the chance of damage during electrical storms if set to off.

steps.headline: Put the wall back where you found it.
Install the AC unit.
steps.description: Remove unit front cover and screws that hold the unit inside its case. Pull the unit forward while an assistant holds the case, until it is fully withdrawn. Install the case or sleeve into the opening. Allow several inches of the case or sleeve to protrude from the wall into the room. Measure the amount of protrusion at one of the top corners, and start a screw through the sleeve or case close to this corner into the framework to keep it from moving. Move the case or sleeve in or out so that the other top corner has the same amount of protrusion. Start a screw through the sleeve or case close to this corner into the framework to keep it from moving. Repeat this procedure for the bottom corners, but remember to have the protrusion here 1/4 to 1/2 inch greater than measured at the top. This creates a position for the case or sleeve that is tipped downward to the outside and will minimize the chance for condensation and rainwater from collecting and leaking inside. Once the case or sleeve has been tacked into position, firmly secure it by driving at least two screws into each of the four sides.

steps.headline: Caulk around the unit.
steps.description: Caulk around the inside and outside of the unit by running a generous bead between the unit and the surrounding surface. Extra time spent here will ensure a seal that will help keep water out. Do not scrimp—use a high quality 30-year (or more) caulk rated for use outdoors. Make sure it is paintable.

steps.headline: Install molding.
steps.description: Add trim around the unit inside by cutting appropriate length boards at a 45-degree. Secure with finish nails. Set and fill nail heads and paint.

text:
Pick a location where the AC will be installed. Try not to locate above electrics and electronics because they may be damaged by condensation from the discharge air grates on very humid days. Plan to keep the bottom of the unit 1 to 5 feet (30 to 150 cm) from the floor to minimize dust from the floor clogging the filter, and condensation forming on the ceiling. Locate the wall studs. Use a stud finder, visually inspect baseboards for nail heads, or rap on the walls with your knuckles—you can hear the sound change from hollow to solid as you rap over a stud. (Commonly, studs are 16 inches apart in the U.S.) Lightly indicate with pencil on the wall where these studs lie. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Roughly indicate the layout of the AC unit on the wall, in such a way that the number of studs to be removed are minimized. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Clear the area. Remove any molding above and below the intended opening location. Remove the drywall between those studs indicated from the floor to the ceiling first by scoring the wall with a razor blade (utility knife) along the inside of the studs. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/38/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/38/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} With a hammer or gloved fist, knock out just enough drywall to locate any wires or other obstructions that could be damaged with a saw. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Use of a utility knife works surprisingly well on drywall, and will result in the least amount of dust and risk of damaging wires and pipes in the wall space. To use the knife, repeatedly score the wall top to bottom. You do not need to completely penetrate through the drywall—just get through 1/2 to 3/4 of the thickness. A sharp hit on the wall with a gloved fist will break the drywall along the scored line. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Alternately, you can saw out the drywall by cutting as close as possible to the side of the studs. Use of hand saws made for drywall will minimize dust. If using a Sawzall or similar, a helper with a vacuum following your cutting path will reduce dust considerably. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Remove the insulation. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet5.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet5.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet5.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Remove the center stud(s) if needed to accommodate the AC unit. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet6.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet6.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet6.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-3Bullet6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Transfer the dimensions of the AC unit or sleeve to the inside of the outside wall. Set the placement of the exhaust opening so that the top will fall just under the edge of a full clapboard, shingle, or other siding section—wherever it will be most aesthetically pleasing (or rather, least aesthetically displeasing). Create the hole for the outside of the unit. Mark the outside opening using a template if provided by the AC manufacturer, or draw one in. If you draw your own template, use a framing square and level to ensure that your opening is level and square. Add 1/4 inch to the height of the opening. This additional 1/4 inch will allow the unit to be angled slightly downward on the outside to prevent condensation and rainwater from collecting in the unit and leaking inside the house. If you have a specific point for the top of the opening, add this 1/4 inch to the bottom for the new line to cut. Carefully create the opening by cutting along the lines with a Sawzall. Build supports. Cut a stud to fit against the two studs that make the sides of the opening created for the AC unit. Level and install at the bottom edge of the AC unit location. Cut a board to fit between the wall stud on the floor in the wall space and the bottom AC support installed in the previous step. Screw or nail these studs to the existing studs. There should be three (possibly four if the unit is very large) new vertical studs in the space below the unit; all of which run from the bottom to the underside of the horizontal support; one in the middle, one against the existing left stud and one against the existing right stud. Fabricate a header. It will be the top of the framework for the opening. Cut two (2 x 4 construction) or three (2 x 6 construction) pieces of the same length from a 2-by. Cut one or two (again, 1 for 2x4 or 2 for 2x6 construction) strips of 1/2" plywood the same size as the 2-bys. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Place the plywood strips between the 2-bys and nail or screw together. The completed header thickness should be very close to 3-1/2 or 5-1/2 inches (for 2x4 or 2x6 construction, respectively). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut two 2-bys equal to the opening height. Secure them against the existing studs in the space for the unit, by resting on the bottom horizontal support previously installed and nail or screw in place. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0d/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0d/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Rest the header on top of the vertical supports installed in the previous step. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Secure the header by nailing or screwing in place. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet5.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet5.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet5.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-7Bullet5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Add studs. Cut a 2-by to fit between the header and the top plate (the 2-by that the left- and right-most studs are secured to at the top) plus 1/8 inch at the left-most stud and nail or screw into place. Hammer these studs into position. Repeat for the right-most stud and for at least as many vertical studs installed in previous steps below the unit, in the space above the new header. If one stud was cut and installed in the middle of the wall space for the bottom support of the unit, then at least one (but more would be better) will be required above the opening as well. These studs above the header should fit tightly. If not a tight fit, cracks may develop on the wall surface as the weight settles on the new framework in the wall. Finish the frame. Cut two 2-bys equal to the height of the opening. Making this cut a little long (1/16 inch or so) will help ensure settling will not reduce the opening and minimize any movement. Hammer these 2-bys along the left and right side of the opening. Nail or screw in place. Install any electrical outlets required while the wall is open. If the unit is high on the wall, consider installing an appropriately rated switch at this time for the outlet, as this will make powering the unit on and off easier. It will also reduce the chance of damage during electrical storms if set to off. Put the wall back where you found it. Reinstall the insulation. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Install the drywall. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Tape, mud (joint compound) and sand when dry. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Paint wall and reinstall all molding. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Install-an-Inwall-Air-Conditioner-Step-11Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Install the AC unit. Remove unit front cover and screws that hold the unit inside its case. Pull the unit forward while an assistant holds the case, until it is fully withdrawn. Install the case or sleeve into the opening. Allow several inches of the case or sleeve to protrude from the wall into the room. Measure the amount of protrusion at one of the top corners, and start a screw through the sleeve or case close to this corner into the framework to keep it from moving. Move the case or sleeve in or out so that the other top corner has the same amount of protrusion. Start a screw through the sleeve or case close to this corner into the framework to keep it from moving. Repeat this procedure for the bottom corners, but remember to have the protrusion here 1/4 to 1/2 inch greater than measured at the top. This creates a position for the case or sleeve that is tipped downward to the outside and will minimize the chance for condensation and rainwater from collecting and leaking inside. Once the case or sleeve has been tacked into position, firmly secure it by driving at least two screws into each of the four sides. Caulk around the unit. Caulk around the inside and outside of the unit by running a generous bead between the unit and the surrounding surface. Extra time spent here will ensure a seal that will help keep water out. Do not scrimp—use a high quality 30-year (or more) caulk rated for use outdoors. Make sure it is paintable. Install molding. Add trim around the unit inside by cutting appropriate length boards at a 45-degree. Secure with finish nails. Set and fill nail heads and paint.
